ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed my ability to analyze classical Arabic texts this semester. At the start of the year, I didn't know much at all about Arabic grammar and morphology and this semester I found myself growing increasingly comfortable reading classical material.
I developed a more extensive understanding of Classical Arabic grammar, in addition to honing skills of reading and comprehension.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of this course is the readings that we examined from the Classical Arabic Reader. It would have been great to study Qur'anic verses and hadith as well though.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to a student interested in classical Arabic literature. Modern Standard Arabic is no substitute to grappling with classical texts and examining grammar and morphology, and this course is the perfect way to engage with material in this way.

If you're into Arabic grammar and classical literature, then you should take this class. The professor is very engaging and dynamic and makes translating classical Arabic poetry/prose very exciting and enjoyable.
